item.title: Gender and Detection
item.dc:creator: lookbadgers
item.description:
I was wondering how accurate the detection is depending on gender, from my findings it seems to work best with males when stringing words together. Is there any sort of setting that can be applied to improve detection for female voices? Even if it is a manual switch within the app, this would greatly improve the experience.

I’m really pleased though with this library, it’s a great bit of kit.

item.title: Reply To: Gender and Detection
item.dc:creator: Halle Winkler
item.description:
Hello,

Nope, no gender switch. The most effective thing I can recommend would be adapting the acoustic model with a large set of speech recordings of female speakers, using only speech related to your language model:

http://cmusphinx.sourceforge.net/wiki/tutorialadapt

item.title: Reply To: Gender and Detection
item.dc:creator: lookbadgers
item.description: Ok thank you for the quick reply. Time to get the mic out!

I’m trying to recognize just one name at a time (keyword-spotting)

btw, I’m generating my model language with this function:

I’m using Rejecto and RapidEars

item.title: Reply To: Gender and Detection
item.dc:creator: Halle Winkler
item.description: Are you using the 2.x acoustic model? It is very surprising to me to hear that it has recognition issues that would be attributable to different genders using it, or that this would even be one of the characteristics that would seriously differentiate different user results. What is the sample size you are testing against? This would prompt a need for time-consuming investigation into the reported problem with different genders, so I need to understand a bit more background on why gender seems like the distinguishing characteristic for different recognition results. Thanks.

item.title: Reply To: Gender and Detection
item.dc:creator: oscarjiv91
item.description: Yes, I’m using 2.x acoustic model. Not sure what you mean with “sample size”. I’m testing it with live speech. Also have this problem with children voices.

item.title: Reply To: Gender and Detection
item.dc:creator: Halle Winkler
item.description: I mean, how many women and men have you tested with respectively? The children’s voices are to be expected, but there being a male/female split is very surprising.
